units.title: Functions Review
units.description: Domain, range, function operations, transformations, and inverses.

content.explanation: The domain is all possible input (x) values. The range is all possible output (y) values. Restrictions: no dividing by 0, no even roots of negatives, and logarithms need positive inputs. Interval notation: [a,b] includes endpoints, (a,b) excludes them.
content.real_world: Engineers define domains when modeling — a bridge length can't be negative.

content.explanation: f(x) means 'the output of function f at input x'. Operations: (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x), (f-g)(x)=f(x)-g(x), (fg)(x)=f(x)·g(x), (f/g)(x)=f(x)/g(x). Composition: (f∘g)(x)=f(g(x)) — apply g first, then f.
content.real_world: Computer programs chain functions together — composition in action.

content.explanation: Starting from y=f(x): f(x)+k shifts UP k. f(x)-k shifts DOWN k. f(x-h) shifts RIGHT h. f(x+h) shifts LEFT h. -f(x) reflects over x-axis. f(-x) reflects over y-axis. af(x) stretches vertically by a. f(bx) compresses horizontally by b.
content.real_world: Video game graphics use transformations to move and resize objects on screen.

content.explanation: The inverse f⁻¹ undoes f: f(f⁻¹(x))=x. To find it: swap x and y, solve for y. The graphs of f and f⁻¹ are reflections over y=x. A function has an inverse only if it's one-to-one (passes horizontal line test).
content.real_world: Encoding/decoding messages uses inverse functions — one encodes, the other decodes.

practice_problems.question: f(x)=x² (all reals) has an inverse function.
Graphs of f and f⁻¹ are reflections over:

units.title: Quadratic Functions
units.description: Vertex form, completing the square, quadratic formula, and discriminant.

content.explanation: Standard form: y=ax²+bx+c. Vertex form: y=a(x-h)²+k where (h,k) is the vertex. If a>0 parabola opens up (minimum). If a<0 opens down (maximum). Axis of symmetry: x=h. In standard form, vertex x-coordinate = -b/(2a).
content.real_world: Projectile paths are parabolas — the vertex is the highest point.

content.explanation: To convert y=ax²+bx+c to vertex form: 1) Factor out a from first two terms. 2) Take half of b/a, square it, add and subtract inside. 3) Factor the perfect square trinomial. Example: x²+6x+1 = (x²+6x+9)-9+1 = (x+3)²-8.
content.real_world: Completing the square is used in GPS calculations to determine position.

content.explanation: For ax²+bx+c=0: x=(-b±√(b²-4ac))/(2a). The discriminant D=b²-4ac tells the nature of roots: D>0 → two real roots, D=0 → one repeated root, D<0 → two complex roots.
content.real_world: The quadratic formula appears in physics for calculating projectile landing times.

content.explanation: Projectile motion: h(t)=-16t²+v₀t+h₀ (height in feet). Revenue: R=price×quantity. Maximum/minimum at vertex. Set equation to 0 to find x-intercepts (zeros). The vertex gives the optimal value.
content.real_world: Companies use quadratic models to find the price that maximizes profit.

practice_problems.question: The vertex of a downward parabola gives:

units.title: Complex Numbers
units.description: Imaginary unit i, complex operations, conjugates, and complex solutions.

content.explanation: The imaginary unit i=√(-1), so i²=-1. Powers of i cycle: i¹=i, i²=-1, i³=-i, i⁴=1, then repeats. For any negative radicand: √(-a)=i√a. Complex number: a+bi where a is real part, b is imaginary part.
content.real_world: Electrical engineers use imaginary numbers to analyze alternating current circuits.

content.explanation: Add/subtract: combine real and imaginary parts separately. Multiply: use FOIL and replace i² with -1. Example: (2+3i)(4+i)=8+2i+12i+3i²=8+14i-3=5+14i.
content.real_world: Signal processing multiplies complex numbers to combine wave signals.

content.explanation: Conjugate of a+bi is a-bi. Product: (a+bi)(a-bi)=a²+b² (always real). To divide complex numbers: multiply top and bottom by the conjugate of the denominator.
content.real_world: Complex conjugates are used in quantum mechanics to calculate probabilities.

content.explanation: When the discriminant D=b²-4ac<0, solutions are complex: x=(-b±i√|D|)/(2a). Complex roots always come in conjugate pairs. Example: x²-2x+5=0 → x=(2±√(-16))/2=(2±4i)/2=1±2i.
content.real_world: Control systems in engineering use complex roots to analyze stability.

practice_problems.question: Complex roots come in conjugate pairs.

units.title: Polynomials
units.description: Operations, factoring, division, and finding zeros of polynomials.

content.explanation: Add/subtract: combine like terms. Multiply: distribute each term. Degree = highest exponent. Leading coefficient = coefficient of highest-degree term. Standard form: descending order of exponents.
content.real_world: Polynomial equations model roller coaster curves and economic trends.

content.explanation: Key patterns: Difference of squares: a²-b²=(a-b)(a+b). Sum of cubes: a³+b³=(a+b)(a²-ab+b²). Difference of cubes: a³-b³=(a-b)(a²+ab+b²). Factor by grouping for 4-term polynomials.
content.real_world: Factoring is used in cryptography to test whether large numbers are prime.

content.explanation: Long division: divide leading terms, multiply, subtract, bring down, repeat. Synthetic division (dividing by x-c): write coefficients, bring down first, multiply by c, add down. Remainder theorem: f(c) = remainder when dividing by (x-c).

examples.explanation: Remainder when dividing by (x-2) is f(2)=4+6+5=15.

content.real_world: Engineers use polynomial division to simplify transfer functions in control systems.

content.explanation: Rational Root Theorem: possible rational zeros = ±(factors of constant)/(factors of leading coeff). Factor Theorem: if f(c)=0, then (x-c) is a factor. Strategy: find one zero, factor it out, repeat.
content.real_world: Finding polynomial zeros helps economists locate break-even points.

practice_problems.question: Possible rational roots of x³+2x-3: factors of ___
If f(3)=0, then ___ is a factor.

units.title: Rational Functions
units.description: Simplify, operate on, and solve rational expressions and equations.

content.explanation: A rational expression is a fraction with polynomials. To simplify: factor numerator and denominator, cancel common factors. State restrictions (values that make denominator 0).
content.real_world: Rates like speed=distance/time are rational expressions in disguise.

content.explanation: Multiply: factor everything, cancel, multiply remaining. Divide: flip the second fraction and multiply. Always factor before canceling.

examples.explanation: Cancel one x and one y.

content.real_world: Pharmacists multiply rational expressions when calculating drug concentrations.

content.explanation: Same denominator: add/subtract numerators. Different denominators: find LCD, rewrite each fraction, then add/subtract. LCD = least common multiple of denominators.
content.real_world: Adding fractions with different units (like combining rates) uses LCD.

practice_problems.question: To add fractions with different denominators:

content.explanation: Multiply both sides by LCD to eliminate fractions. Solve the resulting equation. CHECK for extraneous solutions (values that make original denominator 0).
content.real_world: Rate problems (work, speed) often lead to rational equations.

practice_problems.question: x/(x-3)=3/(x-3). x=3 is extraneous because x-3=___

units.title: Radical and Exponential Functions
units.description: Nth roots, rational exponents, radical operations, and exponential functions.

content.real_world: Compound interest formulas use rational exponents for fractional time periods.

content.explanation: √(ab)=√a·√b. √(a/b)=√a/√b. Simplify by extracting perfect square factors. Add/subtract radicals with same radicand (like terms). Rationalize denominators by multiplying by √n/√n.
content.real_world: Pythagorean theorem calculations often require simplifying radicals.

content.explanation: f(x)=a·bˣ. If b>1: exponential growth. If 0<b<1: exponential decay. Compound interest: A=P(1+r/n)^(nt). Continuously compounded: A=Pe^(rt). Half-life: A=A₀·(1/2)^(t/h).
content.real_world: Population growth, radioactive decay, and bank interest all follow exponential models.

practice_problems.question: Half-life 4 hrs. After 8 hrs, fraction left=1/___

content.explanation: Same base method: if bˣ=bʸ, then x=y. Rewrite both sides with the same base. If bases can't match, use logarithms (covered next unit). Key: 4=2², 8=2³, 9=3², 27=3³, 16=2⁴, etc.
content.real_world: Exponential equations model the spread of viral content on social media.

units.title: Logarithmic Functions
units.description: Logarithm definition, properties, solving equations, and applications.

content.explanation: log_b(x)=y means b^y=x. A logarithm answers: 'What exponent gives me x?' log_b(b)=1. log_b(1)=0. Common log: log=log₁₀. Natural log: ln=logₑ. Inverse: b^(log_b(x))=x.
content.real_world: The Richter scale uses log₁₀ — each unit is 10× more intense.

content.explanation: Product rule: log(ab)=log(a)+log(b). Quotient rule: log(a/b)=log(a)-log(b). Power rule: log(aⁿ)=n·log(a). Change of base: log_b(x)=log(x)/log(b)=ln(x)/ln(b).
content.real_world: Sound decibels use logarithms: dB=10·log(I/I₀).

practice_problems.question: log₃(9)=log(9)/log(___):
practice_problems.hint: Change of base: divide by log(3).

content.explanation: Strategy 1: Convert log to exponential form. log_b(x)=c → x=b^c. Strategy 2: If log_b(A)=log_b(B), then A=B. Always check: argument of log must be positive.
content.real_world: pH in chemistry is solved using logarithmic equations: pH=-log[H⁺].

content.explanation: Compound interest: A=Pe^(rt), solve for t: t=ln(A/P)/r. pH=-log[H⁺]. Richter magnitude: each unit=10× energy. Decibels: dB=10·log(I/I₀). Population doubling time: t=ln(2)/r.
content.real_world: Carbon-14 dating uses logarithms to determine the age of fossils.

practice_problems.question: Each Richter unit is ___ times more intense:

units.title: Trigonometric Functions
units.description: Unit circle, radian measure, graphs, identities, and solving trig equations.

content.real_world: Rotating wheels, pendulums, and orbits all measure angles in radians.

content.explanation: y=A·sin(Bx+C)+D. Amplitude=|A| (height). Period=2π/B (one cycle length). Phase shift=-C/B (horizontal shift). Vertical shift=D. sin starts at 0, cos starts at max. sin and cos have same shape, shifted π/2.
content.real_world: Sound waves are modeled by sine functions — amplitude is volume, frequency is pitch.

content.explanation: Pythagorean: sin²θ+cos²θ=1, tan²θ+1=sec²θ, 1+cot²θ=csc²θ. Quotient: tanθ=sinθ/cosθ. Reciprocal: cscθ=1/sinθ, secθ=1/cosθ, cotθ=1/tanθ. Double angle: sin(2θ)=2sinθcosθ, cos(2θ)=cos²θ-sin²θ.
content.real_world: Engineers use trig identities to simplify wave interference calculations.

content.explanation: Isolate the trig function, then find the angle. Remember: sine and cosine repeat every 2π. Use reference angles and check all quadrants. General solution includes +2πn (n integer).

examples.explanation: sin positive in Q1 and Q2.

content.real_world: Navigation systems solve trig equations to determine direction and heading.

practice_problems.question: tanx=1. x=45° and ___° (0°-360°)
practice_problems.hint: Tan positive in Q1 and Q3.

practice_problems.question: sinx=√2/2. In [0,2π], x=π/4 and:
practice_problems.hint: Sin positive in Q1 and Q2.

practice_problems.question: 2cosx=1. cosx=1/2. x=60° and ___°
practice_problems.hint: Cos positive in Q1 and Q4.
